ImageData.LabelName: b) Cancer in one lymph node near common iliac artery
a) Cancer in more than one lymph node not near common iliac artery
b) Cancer in one lymph node near common iliac artery
a) Cancer in more than one lymph node not near common iliac artery

OriginalSource.Creator: Terese Winslow
OriginalSource.Comment: Added the labels Prostate and Uterus

Highlighted the lymph nodes in the female figure on the R side so they are similar to the male version; moved the label b) to the L side of both figures so that it creates a bit more space for the labels; and moved the lymph node metastases near the common iliac artery to the L side of the figures

Diversity updates: Changed image to a two-panel image and added a stage IIIB female figure (as the right panel); updated skin tone for both figures to FP III or IV to represent Hispanic/Latino; centered the title above the two panels
Removed the cancer that is outside the bladder and not in a lymph node per expert reviewer

Added brackets on each side of the common iliac arteries, going from where they join the main artery at the top to where they branch into the external iliac arteries at the bottom (right where the ureter crosses the blood vessels).

Removed the small a) at the bottom of figure; made the Cancer label point to the cancer spot on the bladder; removed the label “Layer of fat around the bladder"; changed label for Common iliac artery to plural; for a), took the cancer out of the lymph nodes on the red artery and just kept it in the nodes on the blue artery and near the ureter; and made all of the cancer-negative nodes less “shiny”.
First draft, per AJCC updates (8th edition)

ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Two-panel drawing showing stage IIIB bladder cancer in a male (left panel) and a female (right panel); both panels show cancer in the bladder and in (a) more than one lymph node in the pelvis that is not near the common iliac artery and (b) one lymph node near the common iliac artery. Also shown are the right and left common iliac arteries, the prostate (left panel), and the uterus (the right panel).

Two-panel drawing showing stage IIIB bladder cancer in a male (left panel) and a female (right panel); both panels show cancer in the bladder and in (a) more than one lymph node in the pelvis that is not near the common iliac artery and (b) one lymph node near the common iliac artery. Also shown are the right and left common iliac arteries, the prostate (left panel), and the uterus (the right panel).

Captions.MediaCaption: Stage IIIB bladder cancer. Cancer has spread to (a) more than one lymph node in the pelvis that is not near the common iliac arteries; or (b) at least one lymph node that is near the common iliac arteries.

Stage IIIB bladder cancer. Cancer has spread to (a) more than one lymph node in the pelvis that is not near the common iliac arteries; or (b) at least one lymph node that is near the common iliac arteries.
